Name: 4 Maccabees
Metaphysical Tags: Monism (Single Principle), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Subversion (Negation), Dialectics (Conflict)
Short Description: A philosophical treatise that argues for the supremacy of reason over emotion, using examples from Jewish martyrdom under Seleucid persecution to illustrate its thesis. Through the dramatic stories of the aged priest Eleazar, the seven brothers, and their courageous mother, the text blends Stoic philosophy with Jewish theology, showing how devout reason enables individuals to endure suffering and death in loyalty to divine law. Written under early Roman Empire, it serves as both a moral exhortation and an apologia for Jewish faith in a Hellenistic context.

Name: The Jewish War (De Bello Judaico)
Metaphysical Tags: Dialectics (Conflict), Subversion (Negation), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Warfare, Political Science / Law, Sociology, Education, History, Philosophy
Short Description: A seven-book historical account chronicling the Jewish revolt against Roman rule from 66–73 CE, written by the Jewish historian and former general Flavius Josephus. The text begins with a sweeping overview of Jewish history, geography, and cultural origins to contextualize the war. It then details the escalating tensions, internal factionalism among Jewish rebels, and the devastating Roman military campaign led by Vespasian and Titus. Josephus, who defected to the Roman side, attempts to explain and justify his actions while presenting the revolt as tragic and futile.

Name: Antiquities of the Jews
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle), Subversion (Negation)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Political Science / Law, Education, History, Philosophy, Anthropology
Short Description: A monumental 20-volume historical work, aiming to present a comprehensive history of the Jewish people from Creation to the outbreak of the First Jewish–Roman War (66 CE). Josephus begins with Genesis, retelling biblical stories with Hellenistic stylistic conventions, then transitions into post-biblical events, including the rise of the Hasmonean dynasty, the Herodian rule, and Roman governance. The work ends shortly before the Jewish War, which he covers separately in his earlier text. While retelling sacred history, Josephus emphasizes Jewish moral law, prophetic tradition, and rational historical causality, often harmonizing Jewish narratives with Greco-Roman historiographical norms. His political goal was to legitimize Jewish culture to Roman elites and defend it against misrepresentations, presenting Judaism as an ancient, rational, and ethically superior tradition.

Name: Odes of Solomon
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Phenomenology (Experiential), Monism (Single Principle), Subversion (Negation), Becoming (Process Ontology)
Short Description: A collection of 42 mystical hymns express themes of divine union, spiritual rebirth, inner illumination, and joyful liberation from death and darkness. Blending Yahwistic, Christian, and Gnostic elements, the odes voice ecstatic praise, often in the first person, reflecting the soul’s ascent to God through grace. Though attributed pseudonymously to Solomon, the text is anonymous and was likely used in liturgical or initiatory contexts by early Jewish-Christian communities.

Name: Address to the Greeks (Oratio ad Graecos)
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Becoming (Process Ontology), Monism (Single Principle), Subversion (Negation)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Education, Political Science / Law, Theology, Literature, Philosophy, History
Short Description: A polemical oration attacks Greek religion, culture, and philosophy while defending the superiority of Christian revelation. Tatian ridicules Greek myths for their immoral, anthropomorphic gods and criticizes philosophers for inconsistency and contradiction. He argues that Hebrew wisdom, embodied in Moses and the prophets, is far older and more trustworthy than Greek traditions, and that true philosophy is found only in Christianity. The work’s purpose is both apologetic (defending Christianity against charges of novelty and barbarism) and subversive (undermining Greek cultural supremacy). Tatian presents Christians as bearers of an ancient, divinely revealed truth that surpasses the unstable systems of pagan thought and practice.

Name: Chronicle (Chronicon)
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Political Science / Law, Sociology, Linguistics, History, Philosophy, Anthropology
Short Description: A two-part universal history that aligns events from different cultures within a single chronological framework. The first part (Chronographia) compiles historical narratives from biblical, Greek, Roman, Egyptian, and other sources, while the second part (Chronological Canons) presents parallel columns of rulers, events, and dates from various civilizations, allowing readers to compare timelines. Written in Greek but preserved mainly in later translations, it is one of the earliest attempts to create a synchronized, global history, serving both scholarly and Christian apologetic aims.

Name: Aethiopica (The Ethiopian Story)
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Subversion (Negation)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Psychology, Literature, Art / Aesthetics, Philosophy, Anthropology
Short Description: A Greek prose romance recounting the adventures of Chariclea, an Ethiopian princess raised in Delphi, and Theagenes, a Thessalian nobleman. After falling in love during a Pythian festival, they elope together under the guidance of the priest Calasiris. Their journey is filled with trials: shipwrecks, kidnappings by pirates, confrontations with bandits, and repeated separation and reunion. The narrative, framed in a complex, episodic structure, moves through Egypt, the Mediterranean coast, and finally Ethiopia, where Chariclea’s true royal lineage is revealed. At first condemned to death as a foreign intruder, she is saved when her parentage is recognized, and both she and Theagenes are restored to honor. The novel combines adventure, romance, and ethnographic description, exploring themes of divine providence, cultural identity, chastity, and the endurance of true love. It ends with the lovers united and accepted in Ethiopia, their trials interpreted as part of a divinely guided destiny.

Name: Against Hierocles
Arts and Sciences Tags: Education, Political Science / Law, Philosophy, History
Short Description: A Christian apologetic work responding to the Roman official Hierocles, who had compared Jesus unfavorably to the pagan philosopher-mystic Apollonius of Tyana. Eusebius summarizes Hierocles’s claims and then refutes them, challenging the credibility of Philostratus’s Life of Apollonius and arguing that Apollonius’s supposed miracles lack reliable evidence and enduring effect. In contrast, he presents Jesus’s works, moral teaching, and the continuing spread of Christianity as proof of divine origin.

Name: On the Martyrs of Palestine
Arts and Sciences Tags: History, Political Science / Law, Psychology, Philosophy
Short Description: An account chronicling the persecution and execution of Christians in Caesarea and other parts of Roman Palestine during the Diocletianic persecutions (303–311 CE). Written by an eyewitness, it narrates the steadfastness, torture, and deaths of numerous martyrs—men, women, and even children—who refused to renounce their faith despite imperial edicts. The work serves both as historical record and moral exhortation, framing martyrdom as a triumph of faith over imperial cruelty, and portraying the martyrs as spiritual athletes who win an eternal crown.

Name: Preparation for the Gospel (Praeparatio Evangelica)
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Education, Political Science / Law, Linguistics, History, Philosophy, Anthropology
Short Description: This 15-book apologetic treatise aims to prepare educated pagans for conversion to Christianity. Eusebius first dismantles pagan religion and mythology, exposing their immorality and contradictions, then critiques Greek philosophy for failing to attain divine truth without revelation. He argues for the antiquity and superiority of the Hebrew prophetic tradition, using extensive quotations from Jewish, pagan, and early Christian sources. The work frames the Roman Empire as providentially ordained for the spread of the Gospel and positions Christianity as the true heir to both Hebrew scripture and the noblest elements of Greek thought, paving the way for his companion work, Demonstratio Evangelica.

Name: Proof of the Gospel (Demonstratio Evangelica)
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Education, Political Science / Law, History, Philosophy, Anthropology
Short Description: This multi-book apologetic work proves that Jesus Christ is the fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy and the culmination of God’s plan for humanity. Eusebius structures his case through close scriptural interpretation, showing how the promises to the patriarchs, prophecies of the Messiah’s birth, works, death, and resurrection, and predictions of the Gentiles’ conversion converge in Christ. He argues that the spread of Christianity under the Roman Empire is divinely ordained, replacing both Jewish ceremonial law and pagan religion. Together, Praeparatio and Demonstratio Evangelica form a masterclass in rhetoric, weaving theological, political, and cultural realities into a unified defense of Christianity.

Name: Ecclesiastical History
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Education, Political Science / Law, History, Philosophy, Anthropology
Short Description: The first major attempt to narrate the history of the Christian Church from the time of Christ to the author’s present day. Spanning ten books, it traces the ministry of Jesus, the work and martyrdom of the apostles, the succession of bishops, missionary expansion, theological controversies, persecutions under Roman emperors, and the eventual triumph of Christianity under Constantine. Drawing on scripture, earlier historians, official documents, and eyewitness accounts, Eusebius presents the Church’s survival and growth as proof of divine providence.

Name: Life of Constantine
Metaphysical Tags: Dialectics (Conflict), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Education, Public Relations, Political Science / Law, History, Philosophy
Short Description: A biography and a political-theological tribute to Emperor Constantine the Great, written by his contemporary and admirer, Bishop Eusebius. It narrates Constantine’s rise to power, his military victories (including the defeat of Maxentius), and his role in ending persecution of Christians through the Edict of Milan. Eusebius emphasizes Constantine’s patronage of the Church, convening of the Council of Nicaea, and building of monumental churches. The text portrays the emperor as God’s chosen ruler, guided by divine vision, and as a model Christian monarch whose reign fulfills divine prophecy.
